Alternatives

I‚Äôm going to talk a bit about designing graphics for broadcast TV.
Why TV? You don‚Äôt have to use TV! There are other opportunities to get a message out to large audiences, even once we rule out the smaller, more fragmented things like social media.
The other visual media are newspapers and digital. But these are very different.
What‚Äôs the difference between these two stories?

Attention span

The big difference is the time and the energy users are investing.
At one end is long-form journalism. Users here are looking for insightful content, but you have to reward their attention, because every paragraph is an opportunity for them to click away permanently.
You have an opportunity to tell a complex story, but it has to progress slowly enough in its complexity to keep users following all the way.
At the opposite end of the scale, in broadcast news, people are more likely to stay watching but not very likely to be engaged.
They‚Äôre probably multi-tasking: scrolling online, cooking dinner, talking to family members.
Whole segments might be a minute or two, but your opportunity to communicate is probably just a few seconds, because someone may not have seen the minute or two beforehand.
You need to work with very little context.

Types of folks you‚Äôll meet

Media is rarely a one person show!
In broadcast, a reporter may contact you as part of a story. They might be building a news segment on their own or working with an editor, a camera operator or others, depending on the size and ambition of the story.
You might also find a presenter reaching out to you directly. Some presenters have a large hand in writing stories, especially at smaller, regional newsrooms where the resources to support them don‚Äôt exist. They could be doing the whole story on their own!
Some newsrooms may have access to a separate team that handles graphics. These are folks who‚Äôre experienced with apps like Creative Cloud, and potentially also specialised software for things like weather graphics. Some newsrooms may share graphics teams across cities, and in some newsrooms the presenter could be doing the graphics themself!
Most broadcast newsrooms have a news director deciding which stories will make the program and how much time each story will get. It‚Äôs not unusual for story timing to change live as the show is broadcasting, so be aware that presenters or reporters may find themselves with less time to present a story than they‚Äôd expected when the show began.
Print and digital are largely split up into reporters and editors. Editors don‚Äôt just check for typos: they make decisions about whether content should be cut, whether content needs to be added, whether the story will make sense to readers, how a story will look in the context of other stories. They‚Äôre analogous to news directors in a lot of ways.



In broadcast:
Reporters and producers
Presenters
Graphics teams
News directors

In print and digital:
Reporters/journalists
Editors
Data journalism team
(Data journo, designer, coder)

Newsroom resourcing

All of these people have one thing in common with you: they have no time at all.
Academia crushes people with rolling long-term project milestones, but the media crushes people with fast-paced, day-to-day deadlines.
If a journalist calls you with a media request and says they have an hour or two for a response, it‚Äôs not just because they aren‚Äôt familiar with the pace of science: it‚Äôs because they were given the story today and it has to be filed today. As well as chasing contacts for other stories, finding graphics for stories, and everything else.
Newsroom resources have been shrinking for a decade - the advertising business is busted.
If you‚Äôre a disaster researcher, they‚Äôre calling you when something bad is happening. They‚Äôre rushed, you feel pushed, stakes are high, everyone is angry.
Taking the time to prep resources when a disaster isn‚Äôt happening, to identify journalists who might be on your beat, and to get practice working with them pays dividends (like all practise!)
It takes way more effort, but journalists will remember a good source when the Big Story rolls around, and it‚Äôs a much better time to hit potentail gotchas.

Journalists who are looking for a particular story are time-poor
Look for opportunities to push stories to journalists and develop relationships

section: Things to remember (for doing media) during a disaster
text:
Things to remember (for doing media) during a disaster

If an active disaster is happening and you get a media request, ask questions of the producer or reporter about the story context.
Will the piece air during the news or during an analysis show? The latter may have more room for context to build.
If you provide graphics during a disaster, be aware of how they may look without context. Could this map of historical earthquake hotspots be mistaken for a forecast? What can you do to ammeleorate the risk of confusion?
If you have the time, check the broadcaster out and look at their graphics. Are they using language, icons or colours around warnings? Avoid those!


Ask questions about context

What kind of show is it? News? Analysis?

Graphics context

Do your titles and labels make the non-emergency context clear?
Do colours, icons or words conflict with official warning messaging?

Audience: the public?
Audience: evening news audience
Time: about 7 seconds
Our purpose: present evidence of climate change
Our point: summer days warming up near you





Here‚Äôs an example of a time series from my last job, running during the weather segment in the evening news.
In this case, the graphics team took the graphic we supplied and remade it.
First question: who‚Äôs our audience? We could just say the public, but let‚Äôs be more specific and say that it‚Äôs people watching the evening news.
That tells us a few more things: they don‚Äôt have much time. About 7 seconds, and they might be multi-tasking.
Our purpose here was to present evidence of climate change.
But that‚Äôs not the point.
The point is that things are warming up close to home.

Primary messages


Trend line up
Getting warmer


Secondary messages


Year-to-year variability
Length of data record





There‚Äôre a lot of potential messages in this chart.
But the first things people see emphasise our point.
Everything else is secondary. If we‚Äôre lucky, astute viewers might understand that the climate varies from year to year, or that we have a long, authoritative record here.
These graphics were designed to be repeated each month; maybe people will pick these messages up with repeated views.
But the primary message is designed to be understood even if someone reads the headline and misses the chart.
Or if they just see the rising trend line and the orange background but miss everything else.

As researchers, you have the opportunity to build social consensus for a policy action, for change or to just help people understand
(It‚Äôll help you talk to your colleagues, too!)

You can use visuals and stories to many ends - to change policies, to change behaviours, or just to help people understand the world.
Or to better talk to each other!

Relating climate to weather


Jargon
daily maxima
maximum daily maximum
area-averaged temperature

(Possible) alternative
daytime temperatures
hottest day
temperature across Australia



‚ÄúClimate is what we expect; weather is what we get‚Äù
A good chunk of physical climate is the patterns we see across time and the three dimensions of space
That means we have a lot of jargon for talking about spatial and temporal scales
This is a tricky dance: in some cases we can get away with an apparent loss of precision in our words, because of the context.
‚ÄúDaytime temp‚Äù != ‚ÄúMaximum temperature‚Äù, but audiences have been trained to relate the two. (So long as the difference isn‚Äôt important to this application!)
The other interesting thing is that people‚Äôs intuition starts to drift - not just with complexity in the measure, but with the time and especially space scales
When we talk about daily temperature in a city, people link it to their experience
If we talk about a hot day across Australia, that‚Äôs a little harder to grasp!
Once you get to the point of a country or the globe having a hot or cold year, it starts to be more of an intellectual exercise

Trickier jargon
eg. extreme rainfall

Num. days ‚â• fixed threshold
Num. days ‚â• historical quantile
% total rain falling on those days
Rainiest 3-day stretch
Rainiest 5-day stretch
etc.


This trade-off becomes more difficult as our statistics start to become indices.
There are many ways to characterise extreme rainfall:
The difference between these may not be important for your audience - it might be enough to say ‚Äúthere are more wet days‚Äù or ‚Äúwe‚Äôre seeing more extreme rainfall‚Äù
But if our conclusion is sensitive to the choice of index, we could have a communication problem
The solution then might not be ‚Äúuse a very long compound noun or an acronym‚Äù; it may be ‚Äúthis story is more complex than we thought‚Äù.
We need to ask ourselves about our purpose and our point again.

In a broadcast TV graphic, the point is basically the whole thing!
This piece on the right is a longform scrollytelling piece.
You might be tempted to think that you have more time here
But the point is still important! People can and do close out of articles if the message doesn‚Äôt land
Scrollytelling pieces often build a complex visual up piece-by-piece. That‚Äôs important to help the reader understand.
But that doesn‚Äôt mean they start the story with the meaning of chart axes or colours.
The point emotionally invests viewers. Then you can add context to the point and explain the need to go complex.
Then you can build a visual up.
